name: Lily
comment info:
I notice that only two of the fifteen largest transit agencies have had growth in their bus ridership. Modern technology and gentrification have likely caused a reduction in public transportation services. In the last nine years the use technology and hand held devices has increased and made traveling more convenient, quicker, and cheaper. With growing technology, calling car companies like Uber is easy. Some people are now able to telecommute or work at home instead of going to work by bus. Gentrification is when old buildings, that are in the city, are replaced with costly and modern skyscrapers and condos. This is likely causing people who moved out of the city to come back in and live close to their work, allowing them to walk instead of riding the bus like before. 

I wonder if transit agencies are having to increase bus fees because there are less riders. Transit agencies have to maintain a stable income in order to be sustainable. 

My headline: Too Many Empty Seats

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Lily --

You are right that transit agencies have to sustain themselves.  What is another source of revenue besides fares?  

You can read more about transit agencies finances in the Vice Media’s Motherboard March 10, 2020 article “Coronavirus May Have a Lasting Impact on Public Transit Funding” (https://tinyurl.com/PubTransVirus).
Why would we care about the decline in bus systems?  What could be do about the decline.

name: Lexi Mackey
comment info:
I notice that for both graphs, bus ridership in the majority of the cities fell from 2010/ 2011 to 2020. For only two cities did bus ridership rise. I also notice that the rate at which ridership falls/ rises varies between cities. Some levels change at more rapid rates (which is evident because of the steeper lines). Also, some cities increase before they decrease (and vice versa) and experience influxes. Something else I notice is that all the lines representing cities with decreases in bus ridership are orange, and the cities which experienced a rise are represented by grey lines (Graph 1). For the second graph, all of the lines are different colors. 

Something that I wonder is why exactly this decrease in bus ridership is happening. And, is the reason the same for all of the cities or is there several reasons as to why this decline is occurring? 

In these graphs, bus ridership from the years 2010/2011 to 2020 is displayed for some of the largest transit agencies in the U.S. (The second graph is four additional cities.) The overall trend is that bus ridership has decreased - pretty significantly for some of the agencies. Interestingly, several cities had influxes in certain years where the bus ridership was on the rise before finally decreasing up to 2020. For only two cities did ridership increase overall, though. A catchy headline for this graph(s) would be "Riders Are Falling Off The Route."

replies.name: L
replies.comment info:
@Lexi Mackey 

You wrote a very imaginative headline! I agree with your observation that the rate first increases then suddenly decreases.

name: Nathan C
comment info:

Companies such as Uber use carpooling as an alternative to taxis, which really reduces the amount of traffic. Working from home is also bigger than it has been before, which means that less people will leave their home. Both Seattle and San Francisco have also gained over 75 thousand people in the last 10 years, which could also explain why there has been a rise in the amount of people riding the bus.  
I wonder if the cause of the decrease in most other major bus lines is due to America having a large amount of oil on hand. If the gas prices are cheaper, than the amount of people riding the bus could decline.
Headline: The decline behind America's usage of public transport.

name: Moderator Bill Gottschalk
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs:  “Is Riding the Bus Outdated?” by Jaxine of Honolulu, "Have You Rode the Bus Lately?" by Nathaniel of Academy For Software Engineering of New York City, "Why Are Bus Riders Being Driven Away?" by Addison of Gladeville Middle School in Mount Juliet, Tennessee, and "Have Bus Riders Reached Their Last Stop?" by Bradlee in Oxford, AL.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, April 9 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and a few Stat Nuggets.

The next graph will be released in two days -- Friday, April 10, with moderation on Wednesday, April 15.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to “What's Going On In This Graph?”  The topic --  how intervening sooner could reduce the effects of the coronavirus.

You can see all of the released graphs on the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” homepage.  Or, go to our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom? Here Are 34.” for an index by context and an index by type of graph.

The link for the Stat Nuggets archives ishttps://tinyurl.com/StatNuggets.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, who takes the bus but prefers the train or walking, and Bill Gottschalk, who rides the bus to St. Louis Cardinals games (but not this year so far!).

name: Moderator
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows what has been happening with bus ridership in the country’s 15 largest transit agencies since 2013.  Here, you see the interactive graph.  If you want a static graph that has Atlanta, Miami, Minneapolis, and Portland, Oregon, go to the link in the release.

There is no consensus on what is causing the decline in bus ridership since 2013, but there are about a dozen hypotheses.  How many can you list and explain?   What additional reasons from the coronavirus could you add to your list?  Return on Friday when we will share the link to the article that included these graphs.  There you can read about these hypotheses.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these visual representations and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released in two days – Friday, April 10 with moderation on Wednesday, April 15.  The graph has not been picked yet, so stay tuned.

name: Angel L.
comment info:
I noticed that there has been an overall decrease in bus ridership since 2010 for the majority of the cities. The only outliers seem to be Seattle and San Fransisco, who both show growth. 
I wonder if certain factors such as the efficiency, cleanliness, and safety of these bus systems could be the cause for these changes. Depending on how low/high these factors are, there could be a few reasons as to why people may not prefer to ride the bus. For, instance, in a city with higher rates of crime on their public transportation, some may turn to another forms of transportation like popular ride-sharing companies  (Uber, Lyft, etc.) many of whom are typically thought to be more convenient and reliable. There could be many other reasons as well, such as competing forms of public transportation (metro systems) or the demographics of the people who live in these cities (those with lower incomes are likelier to rely on public transportation than those with higher incomes).
I think that a catchy headline for these graphs could be "The Fall of America's Bus Systems".
